verses.sanskrit: athaitad apy aśakto'si kartuṃ mad-yogam āśritaḥ | sarva-karma-phala-tyāgaṃ tataḥ kuru yatātmavān ||
verses.transliteration: atha etad api aśaktaḥ asi kartuṃ mad-yogam āśritaḥ | sarva-karma-phala-tyāgaṃ tataḥ kuru yatātmavān ||
verses.translation: If you are even unable to do this (abhyāsa-yoga), then, taking refuge in My yoga, with self-control (yatātmavān), renounce the fruits of all actions.

commentary.dadaji: Beloved child, the Lord is infinitely patient — He keeps offering lower rungs of the ladder for those who find the higher ones too steep. If you cannot fix your mind on Him through practice or meditation, then at least do your work and release the result at His feet. This act of offering every fruit — success or failure, joy or sorrow — is itself a form of refuge in Him. Yatātmavān, the self-controlled one, is simply one who no longer lets the restless ego seize the harvest of action. Even this one step, taken sincerely, begins the inner purification that eventually leads to pure love.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The Gītā's teaching here echoes the Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad's counsel to the householder: live in the world but not be bound by it. Karma-phala-tyāga — renunciation of the fruit of action — is the practical Vedāntic discipline for one not yet established in knowledge or meditation. By withdrawing the sense of personal ownership from results, the ego-knot is gradually loosened. The Māṇḍūkya Upaniṣad points to the Self as the witness of all action; here Kṛṣṇa gives us a behavioral practice that aligns daily life with that insight. Self-control (yatātmavān) ensures that renunciation is genuine and not merely intellectual.
commentary.yogananda: Paramahansa Yogananda taught that karma yoga — action without attachment to results — is the stepping-stone for those whose minds have not yet learned to meditate deeply. By mentally offering every outcome to God, the devotee begins dismantling the ego's compulsive grip on results. Each surrendered fruit is a brick removed from the prison of self-limiting consciousness. The phrase 'mad-yogam āśritaḥ' — taking refuge in My yoga — reminds us that all true spiritual discipline flows from and returns to the divine center within. In this way, even the busiest worldly life becomes an unbroken meditation.
commentary.goyandka: This verse presents the fourth and lowest rung of the spiritual ladder enumerated in the subsequent verse: sarva-karma-phala-tyāga, the renunciation of all fruits of action. The Lord extends this counsel to the utterly incapable aspirant, showing His boundless compassion. By the qualifier yatātmavān — one possessed of self-mastery — the Lord indicates that mere outward renunciation of results without inner discipline is insufficient. Āśritaḥ (taking refuge) confirms that even this practice must be grounded in surrender to the Lord rather than performed as a self-sufficient effort. This verse thus completes the practical hierarchy of sādhanā presented across verses 8 through 11.

verses.sanskrit: śreyo hi jñānam abhyāsāj jñānād dhyānaṃ viśiṣyate | dhyānāt karma-phala-tyāgas tyāgāc chāntir anantaram ||

verses.translation: Better indeed is knowledge than mere mechanical practice; better than knowledge is meditation; better than meditation is renunciation of the fruits of action — from renunciation, peace immediately follows.

word_breakdown.meaning: better, superior; refers to what is ultimately beneficial (not merely pleasant)

commentary.dadaji: This verse is a golden staircase — abhyāsa, jñāna, dhyāna, tyāga, śānti — each step more luminous than the last. The Lord is tenderly showing us that rote practice without understanding is a lesser light; understanding deepens into meditation, and meditation matures into that effortless letting-go where even the meditator disappears. And then — anantaram — immediately, without waiting, peace arrives. This 'immediately' is the Lord's great assurance: tyāga is not followed by a long journey to peace; peace is the very face of true renunciation. Such is the mercy of the teaching.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: This verse encapsulates the entire Vedāntic progression from kriyā to vijñāna. Abhyāsa without jñāna is like rowing a boat without knowing the destination; jñāna illuminates the purpose and direction of practice. Dhyāna, which the Māṇḍūkya Upaniṣad's tradition equates with nididhyāsana (profound meditative contemplation), carries the meditator into direct proximity with the truth. But it is karma-phala-tyāga — the radical non-grasping that arises when the ego's stake in outcomes dissolves — that marks the threshold of liberation. 'Śāntiḥ anantaram': peace not as a future acquisition but as the immediate disclosure of what was always already present.
commentary.yogananda: Yoganandaji called this the law of spiritual ascent: each higher discipline contains and surpasses the lower ones. Mere mechanical repetition of mantra or technique — however dedicated — is transformed when the intellect grasps why it is done and for whom. Meditation then takes that understanding and burns it into direct experience of God's presence. Finally, tyāga — the inner release of all personal desire for outcomes — dissolves the last membrane between the soul and the Infinite. The word anantaram is Kṛṣṇa's guarantee: the moment you truly let go, peace rushes in like sunlight into a room whose curtain has just been drawn aside.
commentary.goyandka: The verse presents an ascending hierarchy of spiritual disciplines, each excelling the preceding: mechanical practice (abhyāsa) is surpassed by knowledge of its purpose (jñāna), which is surpassed by meditation (dhyāna), which is itself surpassed by renunciation of the fruits of all actions (karma-phala-tyāga). The superlative position of tyāga is theologically significant — it represents the complete neutralization of the saṃskāra-generating power of action, which is the root of continued rebirth. The concluding phrase 'tyāgāc chāntir anantaram' — peace directly and immediately from renunciation — confirms that this is not a remote eschatological promise but a this-worldly attainment available to the sincere aspirant.

verses.sanskrit: adveṣṭā sarva-bhūtānāṃ maitraḥ karuṇa eva ca | nirmamo nirahaṅkāraḥ sama-duḥkha-sukhaḥ kṣamī ||
verses.transliteration: adveṣṭā sarva-bhūtānām maitraḥ karuṇaḥ eva ca | nirmamaḥ nirahaṅkāraḥ sama-duḥkha-sukhaḥ kṣamī ||
verses.translation: He who hates no being, who is friendly and compassionate to all, who has no 'mine'-ness and no ego, who is equal in pleasure and pain, and who is forbearing...

toward all beings, all living creatures without exception
friendly, one who is a friend to all; full of maitri (loving-kindness)

equal in sorrow and happiness; undisturbed by pain or pleasure
forbearing, patient; one who endures provocations without retaliation

commentary.dadaji: Here begins the most beautiful section of the entire Gītā — the Bhakta Lakṣaṇa, the portrait of the devotee who is dear to God. And the Lord begins not with grand metaphysics but with the simplest, most universal virtue: adveṣṭā — he hates no one. Not one being. When you love the Lord truly, His presence fills every face and form, and hatred becomes literally impossible. Nirmama and nirahaṅkāra go together — release 'mine' and the ego that creates it falls away too. Then pain and pleasure become equal — not because you feel nothing, but because something deeper than both is always shining.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: This verse inaugurates the Bhakta Lakṣaṇa section, and remarkably, its first quality is adveṣṭā — absence of hatred — not any technique or ritual. This resonates with the Chāndogya Upaniṣad's teaching that the one who sees the ātman in all beings is incapable of harming anyone. Nirmama (no 'mine') and nirahaṅkāra (no ego) are the direct fruits of the Vedāntic realization that there is only one Self appearing as many. When the false identification with the body-mind complex dissolves, the ahaṅkāra and mamakāra that generate conflict dissolve with it. Sama-duḥkha-sukha — equanimity in pleasure and pain — is the natural, unforced state of one established in the non-dual witness.
commentary.yogananda: Yoganandaji taught that love for God must ultimately expand into love for all God's creation — and this verse shows why: adveṣṭā, the non-hating heart, is the outer expression of inner God-union. When we see the same Divine Light shining in all beings, hatred becomes as absurd as one flame hating another. Nirahaṅkāra — the dissolution of ego — is the great spiritual threshold; beyond it, the petty distinctions of 'mine' and 'not mine' simply cease to mean anything. The sameness in pleasure and pain is not stoic numbness but the peace that passes understanding — the peace of a soul anchored in the Unchanging.
commentary.goyandka: This verse commences the celebrated Bhakta Lakṣaṇa section (verses 13–20), in which the Lord enumerates the qualities of the devotee who is dear to Him. The eight qualities in this verse are: adveṣṭā (non-malice), maitratā (friendliness), kāruṇya (compassion), nirmamatā (absence of possessiveness), nirahaṅkāratā (absence of ego), sama-duḥkha-sukhitā (equanimity in pleasure and pain), and kṣamā (forbearance). These are the foundational ethical-emotional qualities. It is significant that the list begins with adveṣṭā — the Lord places the absence of hatred before even positive virtues, indicating that the removal of negative tendencies is the prerequisite for cultivating positive ones.

verses.sanskrit: santuṣṭaḥ satataṃ yogī yatātmā dṛḍha-niścayaḥ | mayy arpita-mano-buddhir yo mad-bhaktaḥ sa me priyaḥ ||
verses.transliteration: santuṣṭaḥ satatam yogī yatātmā dṛḍha-niścayaḥ | mayi arpita-manaḥ-buddhiḥ yaḥ mat-bhaktaḥ saḥ me priyaḥ ||
verses.translation: ...ever content, meditative (yogī), self-controlled, of firm resolve, with mind and intellect dedicated to Me — that devotee of Mine is dear to Me.

commentary.dadaji: And now the crown of the first stanza — sa me priyaḥ, he is dear to Me. All the virtues of verse 13 find their completion here: contentment that never wavers, the inner stillness of a yogī, the steady will of dṛḍha-niścaya, and finally, the total offering of mind and intellect at the Lord's feet. When manas and buddhi are both arpita — offered — nothing remains to pull the devotee away. He has become entirely the Lord's own. This is not cold renunciation; it is the warmest possible intimacy, for the Lord Himself says 'priyaḥ' — beloved. You are beloved of God.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: Verse 14 completes the first stanza of Bhakta Lakṣaṇa. Santuṣṭaḥ satataṃ — always content — points to the Upaniṣadic teaching of the ātman as pūrṇa, ever full; discontentment arises only from identification with the finite. Dṛḍha-niścaya, firm conviction, is the quality the Kaṭha Upaniṣad calls the sharp edge of the razor — without it, the spiritual path is easily abandoned. The crowning quality is mayy arpita-mano-buddhiḥ — mind and intellect fully surrendered to the Supreme — which is the practical expression of the Mahāvākya 'Tat tvam asi': the individual instrument dissolving into the Absolute. 'Sa me priyaḥ' — this is the Lord's supreme confirmation.
commentary.yogananda: Yoganandaji often said that true contentment is not passive resignation but the dynamic joy of one who has found the Infinite within. Santuṣṭaḥ satatam — always content — is the signature of a soul that has ceased seeking happiness outside itself. The yogī here is not merely a practitioner of technique but one who lives in union, whose every breath is an act of communion. Dṛḍha-niścaya — firm resolve — is the spiritual backbone without which all noble qualities remain fragile. And mayy arpita-mano-buddhiḥ is the final surrender: when even the intellect is offered to God, the last wall between the devotee and the Divine collapses, and the Lord whispers across eternity: 'sa me priyaḥ — you are dear to Me.'
commentary.goyandka: This verse, continuing from verse 13, completes the first Bhakta Lakṣaṇa stanza with the declaration 'sa me priyaḥ.' The qualities enumerated — santuṣṭatā (contentment), yoga (meditative absorption), yatātmatā (self-control), dṛḍha-niścayatā (firm resolve), and mayi arpita-mano-buddhitā (mind-intellect surrendered to the Lord) — represent both the ethical and the metaphysical dimensions of devotion. Santuṣṭaḥ satatam indicates that contentment must be continuous, not situational. The phrase mayy arpita-mano-buddhiḥ is the culminating quality: the voluntary and complete offering of the inner instruments to the Lord, which represents the essence of bhakti-yoga as distinct from mere ethical virtue.

verses.sanskrit: yasmān nodvijate loko lokān nodvijate ca yaḥ | harṣāmarṣa-bhayodvegair mukto yaḥ sa ca me priyaḥ ||

verses.translation: He from whom the world is not agitated, and who is not agitated by the world, who is free from joy, envy, fear, and anxiety — he is dear to Me.

commentary.dadaji: What a double grace this verse describes — the devotee neither disturbs the world nor is disturbed by it. This is the sthitaprajña quality, the still lake that reflects the sky without rippling. The four agitations — harṣa (excited joy), amarṣa (irritability), bhaya (fear), udvega (anxiety) — are the four winds that normally never let the mind rest. Freedom from these is not numbness; it is the profound stability of one who has found his home in God. When you are free, your very presence becomes a gift: the world is not agitated by you, and you carry within you a peace that no circumstance can disturb.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: This verse presents the sthitaprajña dimension of bhakti — the quality of one whose wisdom is steady under all conditions, as described in Chapter 2. The bilateral symmetry is philosophically precise: yasmān nodvijate loko (the world is not disturbed by him) and lokān nodvijate (he is not disturbed by the world). The Vedāntic explanation is clear — one who has realized the non-dual Self cannot be a source of harm to others, because he sees himself in all; nor can the world harm him, because he is established in the Unchanging. The four agitations — harṣa, amarṣa, bhaya, udvega — correspond to the four primal errors of the ego: grasping, resenting, fearing, and worrying.
commentary.yogananda: Paramahansaji often quoted this verse as the description of the true Master: he neither disturbs nor is disturbed. He wrote that the liberated yogi moves through the world like a boat on water — the boat is on the water, but the water is not in the boat. Harṣa (elation) and amarṣa (irritability) are the two faces of ego-reaction to pleasant and unpleasant events; bhaya (fear) and udvega (anxiety) are its two faces when confronting future uncertainty. Freedom from all four is not achieved by suppression but by realizing that the ego itself — the source of all four — is a fiction built on mistaken identity. In that realization, all four dissolve, and only the divine peace remains.
commentary.goyandka: This verse delineates the social dimension of the ideal devotee's character through a striking double negation: he neither causes agitation in the world nor is he himself agitated by the world's provocations. The four specific agitations from which he is free — harṣa (excessive joy at pleasant events), amarṣa (impatience at obstacles), bhaya (fear of adversity), and udvega (anxious restlessness) — represent the full spectrum of reactive mental states. These four are identified as the root disturbances that prevent spiritual absorption. The liberated devotee's freedom from them is not achieved through avoidance of circumstances but through inner transformation, making him a stabilizing presence in any environment.

verses.sanskrit: anapekṣaḥ śucir dakṣa udāsīno gata-vyathaḥ | sarvārambha-parityāgī yo mad-bhaktaḥ sa me priyaḥ ||

verses.translation: He who is without expectation, pure, capable/expert, indifferent (udāsīna), free from distress, who has given up all initiating of enterprises — that devotee of Mine is dear to Me.

commentary.dadaji: Anapekṣa — without expectation — is one of the most liberating qualities described here. The moment we expect something from a person, a situation, or even from God Himself, we have already contracted our heart. The free devotee has no such contracts with the world. Udāsīna is beautifully translated as a 'neutral witness' — not cold or indifferent to love, but unentangled in outcomes. And sarvārambha-parityāgī — giving up all self-initiated projects — means he acts only when the Lord moves through him, not when the ego plots and plans. His life is clean, capable, and utterly open. And so the Lord says again: sa me priyaḥ — he is dear to Me.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The quality udāsīna is central to Vedāntic understanding: the witness-consciousness (sākṣī-cetana) that is the ātman is by nature udāsīna — uninvolved, non-attached, merely witnessing. The devotee who embodies udāsīnatā is living from that witness-level of consciousness rather than from the reactive ego. Anapekṣa (no expectation) corresponds to the Vedāntic understanding of the pūrṇa ātman — the Self is already complete and therefore expects nothing. Sarvārambha-parityāga — renunciation of all enterprises — does not mean inaction but the absence of ego-initiated agendas; action still occurs, but it is not 'my' action for 'my' purposes. The result is gata-vyatha — freedom from anguish.
commentary.yogananda: Yoganandaji's commentary on udāsīna was that the liberated master acts like the sun — it shines equally on all, without preference or expectation, and is not diminished by what it illumines. Anapekṣa — no expectations — is the psychological freedom of one who has realized the Self as the source of all fulfillment; such a one literally has nothing to expect from the world because he carries the whole treasury within. Sarvārambha-parityāgī points to the ego's most subtle activity: the planning and initiating mind that always has its own agenda. When that ego-agenda dissolves, action becomes divine play — dakṣa (skilled and graceful) but without any grasping. Śuci — purity — is the natural fragrance of such a life.
commentary.goyandka: This verse adds a further set of characteristics to the portrait of the ideal devotee. Anapekṣa indicates freedom from dependence on external persons or circumstances for one's sense of well-being, which is made possible by unshakeable faith in the Lord's providence. Śuci (purity) encompasses both bāhya-śuci (external cleanliness) and ābhyantara-śuci (internal purity of thought and intention). Dakṣa (skill/capability) indicates that renunciation does not produce incompetence; the devotee performs his duties with excellence precisely because he is unencumbered by anxiety. Most notably, sarvārambha-parityāgī — complete renunciation of all self-initiated enterprises — means the devotee undertakes nothing from personal desire but acts only in accordance with dharma and divine will.

verses.sanskrit: yo na hṛṣyati na dveṣṭi na śocati na kāṅkṣati | śubhāśubha-parityāgī bhaktimān yaḥ sa me priyaḥ ||

verses.translation: He who does not rejoice, does not hate, does not grieve, does not desire, who has abandoned both auspicious and inauspicious outcomes — he, the devotee, is dear to Me.

does not desire, does not crave; free from longing for future acquisitions

commentary.dadaji: Four negative forms — na hṛṣyati, na dveṣṭi, na śocati, na kāṅkṣati — and they paint a portrait of perfect inner freedom. This devotee is not a stone; he loves, he works, he lives fully. But the reactive swings — the elation, the hatred, the grief, the craving — have ceased. And then the crown: śubhāśubha-parityāgī — beyond good and bad. This is where most of us stop and say 'How is that possible?' But the Lord does not say 'indifferent to good and bad' — He says the devotee has gone beyond the very categories of lucky and unlucky, because God alone is his reference point now. Such a one is bhaktimān — truly a devotee — and the Lord's heart opens: sa me priyaḥ.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The four non-reactions of this verse — no elation, no aversion, no grief, no craving — correspond precisely to the four functions of the antaḥkaraṇa (inner instrument): manas (reactive mind), ahaṅkāra (ego-sense), buddhi (discriminating intellect), and citta (memory/desire-storehouse). When none of these is in agitation, the inner instrument becomes a pure mirror reflecting the ātman. The phrase śubhāśubha-parityāgī is philosophically the most significant: it points beyond the ethical duality of good and bad results to the non-dual ground where only pure consciousness (sāk ṣī) remains. This is the junction between bhakti-yoga and jñāna-yoga — the devotee's love has purified him into a sage.
commentary.yogananda: These four negations describe the guṇātīta — one who has transcended the three guṇas — in the language of bhakti. Hṛṣyati (elation) is the pull of sattva when it becomes attachment to pleasantness; dveṣṭi (hate) is tamas expressing through the ego; śocati (grief) is rajas' attachment to the past; kāṅkṣati (craving) is rajas' reach into the future. The one who is free from all four lives entirely in the present moment, in pure awareness. And śubhāśubha-parityāgī — beyond auspicious and inauspicious — is the devotee who has passed through all moral dualities into the divine simplicity where only God is real. Bhaktimān — truly devoted — is the key: this freedom is the fruit of love, not mere discipline.
commentary.goyandka: The four negatives — na hṛṣyati, na dveṣṭi, na śocati, na kāṅkṣati — systematically negate the four fundamental reactive tendencies of the unrefined mind: excessive pleasure in the agreeable, aversion to the disagreeable, lamentation over loss, and craving for the unattained. Together they constitute complete emotional equilibrium. The most elevated quality in this verse, however, is śubhāśubha-parityāga — transcendence of both auspicious and inauspicious outcomes — which indicates that the devotee's consciousness has risen above the plane of karmic merit and demerit entirely. The use of bhaktimān — the possessor of devotion — as a qualifying adjective at this point emphasizes that it is precisely bhakti that produces this state, not mere philosophical detachment.

verses.sanskrit: samaḥ śatrau ca mitre ca tathā mānāpamānayoḥ | śītoṣṇa-sukha-duḥkheṣu samaḥ saṅga-vivarjitaḥ ||

verses.translation: He who is equal to enemy and friend, equal in honor and dishonor, equal in cold, heat, pleasure, and pain, free from attachment...

commentary.dadaji: Sama — equal. This simple word appears twice in this verse like a bell struck twice. Equal to enemy and friend. Equal in honor and dishonor. Equal in cold and heat, pleasure and pain. This is not the equality of indifference — the Lord is not describing a cold machine. He is describing a heart so full of God that it simply has no room left for the discriminations of the ego. The word saṅga-vivarjita — free from attachment — tells us the secret: it is attachment that makes us partial, that makes us prefer friend to enemy and honor to dishonor. Dissolve attachment, and the great equanimity of the soul shines through naturally.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The repeated use of samaḥ (equal) points directly to the Upaniṣadic vision of the ātman as sama — the one unvarying Awareness in which all appearances of difference dissolve. The Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad teaches: 'yasmin sarvāṇi bhūtāni ātmaivābhūt vijānataḥ' — for one who sees the ātman in all beings, what delusion, what grief? The pairs here — enemy/friend, honor/dishonor, cold/heat, pleasure/pain — are the six pairs of opposites (dvandvas) that constitute the phenomenal world. Saṅga-vivarjita — free from all clinging — is the hallmark of the jīvanmukta, the one liberated while still embodied. This verse and the next together describe the guṇātīta as the supreme devotee.
commentary.yogananda: Yoganandaji often said that the spiritual aspirant must cultivate what he called 'even-mindedness' — and this verse is its fullest description. To be samaḥ to enemy and friend is not to pretend there is no difference between them, but to recognize that the same Divine Being looks through both sets of eyes. Māna and apamāna — honor and dishonor — are the ego's most sensitive points; freedom from reaction to both is the sign of a truly liberated consciousness. Śīta and uṣṇa (cold and heat) represent the body's polarities; equanimity there shows that the realized devotee's identity is no longer rooted in bodily comfort. Saṅga-vivarjita — free from all attachment — is the natural state of one who has found the All within.
commentary.goyandka: This verse, continuing into verse 19, constitutes the fifth stanza of the Bhakta Lakṣaṇa. The central virtue here is samatā — equanimity — applied across multiple domains of experience: interpersonal relations (enemy/friend), social standing (honor/dishonor), physical conditions (cold/heat), and inner experience (pleasure/pain). The word samaḥ appearing at both the beginning and middle of the verse structurally emphasizes that equanimity is the theme. Saṅga-vivarjita — free from all attachment — provides the causal explanation: equanimity is the consequence of non-attachment, not of emotional suppression. This verse thus connects the ethical quality of equanimity to its philosophical root in vairāgya (dispassion).

verses.sanskrit: tulya-nindā-stutir maunī santuṣṭo yena kenacit | aniketaḥ sthira-matir bhaktimān me priyo naraḥ ||
verses.transliteration: tulya-nindā-stutiḥ maunī santuṣṭaḥ yena kenacit | aniketaḥ sthira-matiḥ bhaktimān me priyaḥ naraḥ ||
verses.translation: ...who is equal in blame and praise, who is silent (maunī), content with anything, without a fixed home (aniketaḥ), of steady mind — that devotee is dear to Me.

word_breakdown.meaning: equal in blame and praise; tulya = equal, nindā = blame/censure, stuti = praise/commendation
one of silence; mauna can be outer silence of speech or the deeper inner silence of the self
content, satisfied; here specifically, content with whatever comes by chance
with whatever, by whatever means; completely unchoosing in what one accepts
without a fixed home; a pilgrim, unattached to any dwelling or location
of steady mind, unwavering intellect; not shaken by changing circumstances
the devoted one, the possessor of bhakti
that person is dear to Me; naraḥ = man/person, the human being

commentary.dadaji: Maunī — the silent one. This is not merely the one who speaks little; it is the one in whom the inner chatter has grown still. And aniketaḥ — without a fixed home — what a beautiful image. The truly free devotee is a pilgrim, at home everywhere because he carries his home within him. He is content with yena kenacit — whatever comes, however it comes, in whatever measure. There is no minimum requirement on life's generosity. And sthira-mati — the steady mind — is the bedrock beneath all these qualities. The Lord concludes this two-verse stanza with the words me priyaḥ naraḥ — that person — any such person — is dear to Me.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The quality of maunī deserves particular attention from a Vedāntic perspective. The Māṇḍūkya Upaniṣad tradition identifies mauna — silence — with the turīya state, the fourth dimension of consciousness that underlies and pervades all states. The outer maunī, who refrains from unnecessary speech, is a pointer to the inner maunī who abides in the silence of the ātman. Aniketaḥ — without a fixed home — echoes the Muṇḍaka Upaniṣad's description of the liberated sage who wanders free like a flame without fuel. Tulya-nindā-stuti (equal in blame and praise) is the social expression of the same non-dual realization: when the ātman alone is real, what stranger can praise or blame you?
commentary.yogananda: Maunī — inwardly silent — is one of the most beautiful qualities in this list. Yoganandaji taught that the greatest saints are those whose minds have become silent temples, where only God's voice is heard. Aniketaḥ is the quality of spiritual homelessness — not poverty or wandering, but the freedom of one who has made the soul his only home and therefore cannot be displaced from it. 'Yena kenacit' — content with whatever — is the hallmark of one who has found the inexhaustible source of joy within and therefore has no complaint about what life offers from without. Sthira-mati — steady mind — is not rigidity but the deep stability of a tree with roots in the living water of divine consciousness. Such a one, says Kṛṣṇa — me priyaḥ — is dear to Me.
commentary.goyandka: This verse concludes the fifth Bhakta Lakṣaṇa stanza begun in verse 18. The phrase tulya-nindā-stuti — equal in censure and commendation — extends the samatā of verse 18 from physical and interpersonal domains to the verbal and reputational domain. Maunī does not necessarily indicate a vow of silence but rather the discipline of speech: speaking only what is necessary, true, and beneficial. Aniketaḥ — without fixed abode — has been interpreted both literally (the sannyāsī who does not reside in one place for long) and metaphorically (the devotee unattached to any particular worldly situation). Sthira-mati — firmness of mind — serves as the unifying quality that makes all the others stable and enduring rather than temporary states.

verses.sanskrit: ye tu dharmāmṛtam idaṃ yathoktaṃ paryupāsate | śraddadhānā mat-paramā bhaktās te'tīva me priyāḥ ||
verses.transliteration: ye tu dharma-amṛtam idam yathā-uktam paryupāsate | śraddadhānāḥ mat-paramāḥ bhaktāḥ te atīva me priyāḥ ||
verses.translation: But those who follow this nectar of dharma (dharma-amṛtam) as described — with faith, holding Me as the Supreme Goal — those devotees are exceedingly dear to Me.

commentary.dadaji: And so the chapter closes as it could only close — with love. Atīva me priyāḥ — exceedingly, beyond all measure, dear to Me. The Lord has spent this entire chapter describing the path to His heart, and now He opens that heart completely. Dharma-amṛtam — this is not a set of rules; this is nectar of immortality. Every quality described in verses 13 through 19 — the non-hatred, the compassion, the stillness, the surrender — is a drop of this nectar. Śraddadhānā — with faith — is the vessel that receives it, and mat-paramā — holding Me as the Supreme — is the fire that transforms it. Blessed is the devotee who lives these qualities, for the Lord Himself says: you are my beloved beyond all measure.
commentary.sarvapriyananda: The concluding verse of Chapter 12 gathers the entire Bhakta Lakṣaṇa section under two crucial qualifiers: śraddadhānāḥ (with faith) and mat-paramāḥ (holding the Lord as the Supreme). These two qualities are the roots from which all other virtues described grow. The Muṇḍaka Upaniṣad proclaims 'nāyam ātmā pravacanena labhyaḥ... yam evaiṣa vṛṇute tena labhyaḥ' — the ātman is gained by whom the ātman chooses. Here Kṛṣṇa gives the Bhakti Vedānta response: the Lord chooses those who choose Him as Supreme ('mat-paramā') with wholehearted faith. 'Dharma-amṛtam' is a remarkable compound: dharma here is not mere law but the immortal essence of right living — and the Lord calls it nectar, amṛta, pointing to its liberating, life-giving power.
commentary.yogananda: Yoganandaji called this the 'divine conclusion' — the Lord summarizing all of bhakti in one luminous verse. Dharma-amṛtam — the nectar of divine law — is Kṛṣṇa's name for the whole spiritual path He has described, confirming that these qualities are not merely ethical ideals but literally life-giving, immortality-bestowing nectar for the soul. Śraddadhānā — faithful — Yoganandaji said, refers not to blind belief but to the inner conviction born of direct spiritual experience. Mat-paramāḥ — those who hold Me as the Supreme — are those who have tested all the substitutes and found only God to be inexhaustible. For these devoted souls, the Lord's own heart breaks open in the final words of the chapter: atīva me priyāḥ — you are beyond measure, dear to Me.
commentary.goyandka: This concluding verse of Chapter 12 provides both a summation and an elevation. The phrase 'dharmāmṛtam idam yathoktam' — this nectar of dharma as described — refers back explicitly to the entire Bhakta Lakṣaṇa section (verses 13–20) as a unified teaching. 'Paryupāsate' — they who steadily practice — indicates not occasional compliance but consistent, dedicated following of these qualities as a way of life. The two qualifiers śraddadhānāḥ (with faith) and mat-paramāḥ (holding the Lord as the highest) identify the internal disposition without which external practice of these virtues would be merely social or ethical, not liberating. The superlative 'atīva me priyāḥ' — exceedingly dear to Me — surpasses the simple 'sa me priyaḥ' of all preceding stanzas, providing a fitting climax to the chapter's celebration of the path of devotion.
